review_content: Speculative pic on how Gaul's answer to Shakespeare found inspiration in an involuntary gig giving a nobleman acting lessons is sumptuous, touching and often laugh-out-loud funny.

Tirard's risk-free approach of of the life of French comedy's reformer, is as light-hearted and cooky, as Lassel Hallstrom's Casanova, just starring Moliere instead of the infamous womanizer, albeit with a much more European cast.
Two scripters let their imaginations soar to show us how Moliere would act if he became a character of one of his plays and met people from his other productions--and it works!

The film begins on a serious note, requiring an adjustment on the part of the audience toward its more prevalent comic tone. Once that transition is made, the experience of Moliere is an enjoyable one.
Tirard adds just a touch of tragedy for the humor to fully resonate and summons the spirit of his inspiration perhaps more effectively than director John Madden rendered the Bard in heat.
A very silly film.
All in all, it's a breezy, jestful and enjoyable divertissement, in which Duris is given free rein to showcase his considerable versatility.
Enjoyable, frequently amusing and surprisingly romantic French romp with a witty script, superb performances and a subtle message about the value of comedy.
It is all jolly, harmless and amusing - at least until we get back to the "real" France and the ornate wallpaper starts shimmering again.
While this film is rather talky and a long, it's also a wonderfully complex blend of wit and cheekiness, underscored by a surprisingly serious romance and a steely view of the battle of the sexes.
A bit curate's eggy, sometimes funny and always goodlooking, but neither a particularly good tribute to a great playwright nor a comedy with much weight behind it.

It's impossible to avoid comparison with Shakespeare in Love, which similarly made out that many of the great man's plays were really disguised autobiography; but the earlier film had a lightness of touch and variety of tone missing from this one.
Moliere is an exceptionally likeable period comedy, powered by impeccable performances from Luchini and the wonderful Laura Morante.
Just as you should never judge a book by its cover, never judge a film by its press release. Moliere was the most touching, funny film on show this week.
It's a wonderfully witty film - trÃ¨s bien, in fact.

Both a glittering showcase for a literary giant's comic genius and a first-class farce in its own right. By turns funny, mysterious, suffering and sexy, Romain Duris again proves he's the most charismatic French actor working today.
When the French do period drama well, they tend to do it very, very well.
This is no biopic, but pure fantasy, a sort of "MoliÃ¨re in Love" infused with the bittersweet romantic spirit of the playwright's work.

Using a gap in the French playright's bio as a starting point, Tirad's film is a mediocre stab at a Shakespeare in Love-style serio comedy that concocts an imaginary scenario about the ambitious-but-starving young artist--Tim Grierson
Romain Duris may be a superb actor, but a light comedian he ain't. You need a very sweet tooth for this kind of thing.
The film feels distinctly skinny, as if half the cast haven't arrived. The symmetry of the story is almost too perfect. Several leaps of faith are wildly silly.
A witty, lively period drama that expertly blends comedy and tragedy to create a worthy French counterpart to Shakespeare In Love.
Light of touch but overlong, this is saved by a sparkling performance from Romain Duris.
Filmgoers, especially those familiar with MoliÃ¨re's work, will have a great time.
The Shakespeare in Love song remains the same, only the lyrics have changed.
A very satisfying film.

This is the sort of period movie -- that would leave a modern audience with faces of stone. Yet the film, directed by Laurent Tirard, has something. To be exact, it has Fabrice Luchini and Laura Morante...
An especially endearing attempt at the budding subgenre.
A funny, witty, bright, and well-acted costume drama about a fictional turning point in the life of the famous French playwright Moliere.
Duris, so good in The Beat that My Heart Skipped, is simply marvelous here. His MoliÃ¨re is a complex creature of intelligence, insecurity, sincerity, obstinacy and burgeoning brilliance.
Laura Morante proves once again that she is one of the most intelligent and attractive actresses in the world.

Festooned with oodles of museum-worthy 17th century sets and costumes, Moliere is the sort of slightly naughty but literate frolic that congratulates the audience for its good taste; in other words, it's a bit of a snooze.

MoliÃ¨re is as much about the making of a patroness as it is about the gestation of artistic form, for it's she who eggs on the callow playwright to reinvent comedy as serious business with a powerful moral core.
What's missing, alas, is a greater sense of surprise that might keep the film from feeling somewhat rote.
A well-played but ultimately superfluous assortment of your favorite Moliere scenes strung together by a thread-thin plot that emulates, but in no way replaces, the still-sparkling originals.
One of the year's best films to date.
A period piece enlivened with slapstick and mischievous wit.
This movie about the crucible of imagination has none of its own.
Jean-Baptiste Poquelin, better known as MoliÃ¨re, wrote more than 30 plays, every one of them a hundred times more witty and insightful than the movie MoliÃ¨re.
The actors elevate what might have been fluff into a genuinely moving tale, and the action is so much fun that it doesn't even matter if you've seen MoliÃ¨re's plays before.
It may not be a brilliant act of speculative history, but it's a clever and respectable one.
A sweet and silly comedy reminiscent of Shakespeare in Love, it's lushly filmed and gorgeously set and costumed.

A conventional biopic would probably elide most of this period, which was before the pioneering satirist scandalized the establishment with plays like Tartuffe, but the disarming farce Molire, to its great credit, isn't really a biopic.
MoliÃ¨re is a restful diversion, perhaps too restful, but still acceptable. And the actors go a long way toward bringing it off.
A delightful romp with an intriguing story that could have been cut by 30 minutes and not missed a beat.
Laurent Tirard gives us a delightful and witty costume piece about what might have happened in those never-accounted-for months.
Tirard presents MoliÃ¨re like a 17th century Woody Allen - a playwright who yearns to write drama when his forte is farce.
A blithe but satisfying French confection.

The two lead actors are a sight to behold: Romain Duris (Moliere), with his long chin, crooked mouth, asymmetrical moustache, and bewildered eyes, plays off the thin lips and boneless cheeks of Fabrice Luchini's Jourdain.
Director and co-writer Laurent Tirard's pleasant but tame approach to his birth-of-a-major-world-dramatist portrait has its virtues.
Underplays its biggest opportunities for laughs, like the film is standing at the plate but unwilling to swing the bat.

Woefully miscast as the seminal 17th-century French farceur MoliÃ¨re, the intense, black-maned young French movie star Romain Duris never seems more comfortable than the brief moments when he's rotting in a dank jail.
Moliere is an amusing mix of fact and fiction about the life of the brilliant 17th-century French playwright.

In making a comedy about a writer famed for his perfectly tuned wit, the filmmakers have inspired other expectations. The result is as off-putting as biting into a confection in which the sugar has been replaced by salt.
Moliere hardly matches the clever mockery of its 17th century inspiration.
Through homage to Moliere's works and by the film's own example, [director] Tirard reminds us that comedy can provoke both laughter and thought.
As a piece of speculative biography, the movie is unpersuasive.
It nevertheless contains enough wit and charm to keep things humming along even when the plot threatens to bog down into a Gallic version of a typical episode of "Love American Style."
If you've enjoyed Moliere's work, you'll enjoy the film.
Like the playwright's comedies, at its best Moliere shows the depths beneath the archetypes.
The movie leaves initially cynical MoliÃ¨re believing in true love after all, the rock star undone by Hallmark.
Lost in the exercise is any insight into MoliÃ¨re's writing or any relevance to today, making his achievements seem more frivolous -- and considerably less amusing -- than they actually were.
An extravagant and thoroughly irresistible story of intrigue, romance, comedy and artistic inspiration.
Director and cowriter Laurent Tirard are clearly under the sway of Shakespeare in Love, but the talented Duris is miscast as the wily Moliere, and Moliere has none of Shakespeare's giddy charm.
I can only wonder what theatre gods MoliÃ¨re angered during his lifetime to deserve such ragtag biographical treatment, but let's hope MoliÃ¨re settles the debt.
It turns out that a deep appreciation of the human condition can be accomplished through comedy as much as through drama. At least that's what Moliere learns
The unraveling of this same world, 100 years later, was portrayed in Sofia Coppola's Marie Antoinette, next to whose gilded atmosphere the merely glossy MoliÃ¨re looks like a work of naturalism.
Certainly attractive to look at, but what goes on in front of the manicured lawns and sumptuous seventeenth-century interiors is considerably less amusing than it might be.
The cast is very good. The chemistry between Duris and Morante smolders, while Luchini makes a convincing, bungling aristocrat.
It's like a breeze so slight it doesn't leave a tickle.
Connoisseurs of Sun King-era costumes and decor are the most likely fans of this impeccably produced but unimaginative pseudo-biopic...
There's not a single moment that you haven't already seen in a different, better period film.
The film illuminates little about MoliÃ¨re himself, but what do you expect from a movie that has the depth of a kiddie pool?
"Moliere" actually tells a funny, involving story that really does seem inspired by its subject, rather than just lazily cribbing from his work.
An amusing and clever film, often laugh-out-loud funny and filled with sparkling characters.

As the film picks up momentum, however, it becomes the story of an aimless young man who discovers his own brilliant wit and learns how to use it. As he gets closer to the scathing, fearless Moliere we know and love, so does the movie.
For theater people and French literature buffs...a delightful game of spot-the-reference...
Un cuadro social de Ã©poca vivaz y divertido, con estupendo elenco y una cuota de romance y emotividad.

A sumptuous pleasure to behold, with its elegantly designed motifs, infectious energy conveying the emotional sensibility of the time, and splendid comic mischief satirizing the hypocrisy of both the bourgeoisie and aristocracy.
A breezy historical romance with a strong knack for comedy.
Deluxe tribute to the playwright gets by, surprisingly, as much by romantic poignancy as farce...it's hard to dislike a picture so in Love with its subject.
A sophisticated and literate biographical speculation is the basis of this witty and entertaining portrait of the titular artist.

Witty lines, sumptuous settings, manicured lawns and horses with carriages provide the setting for this frivolous romp that caresses history as it plays with the misadventures of French playwright MoliÃ¨re %u2026 With just the right balance of playfulness
MoliÃ¨re has no redeeming qualities.
MoliÃ¨re is as insubstantial as dandelion fluff, and just as apt to blow away in a strong wind.
The film is a shallow study of the ~intoxicating allure of violence', with a few gratuitous tit shots thrown in for good measure.
Exploitative and depressing.
The violence may be too strong for some but this is worth seeing for a terrific performance by Gillian Anderson.
Masculinity in Crisis, part 364.
Payback involving a shotgun, a kitchen table and a heap of pain.
Even if Straightheads looks as if it was made for about 4, it(TM)s been a long time since someone was brave enough to make a such a movie.
Make no mistake: this lo-fi rape-revenge Brit flick wants to shock you.
Country rapists have their way with Gillian Anderson and poke Danny Dyer's eye out. The duo want payback.
This nasty and nonsensical rape-revenge thriller is a feature-length exercise in wrongness.
Straightheads has the pornographic ingredients of a first-rate cult thriller.
Where's Mulder when you need him.
Anderson bares (almost) all in this flawed but fitfully fascinating thriller with a comical, if less compelling, turn from Danny Dyer.
It's clear from the start this isn't a revenge drama that's going to wimp out at the end.
A repellent, ill-thought-through feature.
Feels like an experiment in suspense and violence that doesn't actually tell us anything
The film looks professional and has a relatively big-name star in Gillian Anderson, but the screenplay - written by director Dan Reed - doesn't make a single bit of sense.
About how some of us would be willing to sell our souls to protect our loved ones if we had to...
...a low-key drama disguised as a revenge thriller...
Straightheads is as shallow as a puddle and forgoes anything approaching realism in favour of OTT violence and needless gore.
Berman balances the weight of the actual events with the desire to mount a simply effective horror story, and I think he pulls it off quite well.
Every once in awhile, a film can defy expectations, and Lionsgate's Borderland is one such case.
An unnerving, ruthless, borderline-mesmerizing thriller.
...ultimately descends into a brutal orgy of torture and mutilation that's harrowing to watch, because it's played completely real.

Borderland takes this libertarian view of paradise (no law, no government, just rich people doing what they want) and turns it on its head in a particularly brutal and ugly way, without expressing a political point of view in a heavy-handed way.
...one can't help but admire any film that features a villain with a penchant for saying things like "I'll decorate my bedroom wall with your skin"...
Borderland teeters between a torture film and a spiritual thriller, but it also plays around with both genres in very intriguing ways.
Bluesy background music + a rainy Portland setting enhance the gloomy feel of 'Spiral' and help draw us into the world of its disturbed lead character.
"The camera moves are jarring at times and soothing at others ... a skillful, well crafted piece."
Spiral is an interesting experiment in the evocation of things that do not actually exist, and it succeeds with sizzle.
It's a wit-free homage to Hitchcock and M. Night Shyamalan that, for all its slick presentation, never comes close to hitting the mark of its forebears.
Note to the writers: Just because a movie is a mystery doesn't mean everything in it has to be.
Spiral is a joy to behold on every level.
Is a much different film than "Hatchet." It's focused, it's low key, it's original, and it really takes its plot seriously...
It's an obvious, overlong, determined misfire of a motion picture...ambitious, but it's also fatally flawed.
A surprisingly engrossing two-person character study that (gradually) reveals something quite a bit darker beneath the surface.
one long, slow buildup to a surprise ending that conceals two or three twisting secrets while still remaining elusive and open to interpretation.
...a misguided and thoroughly pointless piece of work.
Less accessible to general auds than The Sun, pic deserves major accolades from fests as well as discerning arthouses.
Stark but moving snapshot of men on the front line of a nation's nightmare.
Though not a top-notch Sokurov, his new film is a conceptually fascinating meditation on war seen from the perspective of an older woman who visits the battle front.
The performance of 80-year-old Vishnevskay is priceless.

Disappointingly uncharacteristic of Sokurov, the humanist moments that pass between them lean toward token sentiment, and the moments that pass between Alexandra and the grandson she traveled so far to see feel inconsequential.
Koyrasmenos dimioyrgika kai thematika, o Sokurov prosferei mia faflatadiki dokimi ton orion tis katatonias
This is as faultless a film as I've seen in a long time - certainly my best film of 2007.
Sokurov applies a thoughtful, humanist spin to the Chechen war - or any war - in this quiet mediation.
I found it incredibly hard to care about either the grandmother or the young men and, since there is no plot to hold your interest, torpor ensues.
hits on something painful and intrinsically human: the feeling of inevitable disillusionment
Spare yet tactile, a mysterious mixture of lightness and gravity.

Russian director Alexander Sokurov brings a political edge to the intra-family dynamics with this relatively straightforward tale of a grandmother's trip to an embattled region of Russia for a visit with her grandson.
Alexandra is a much more modest undertaking, but is just as compelling. And Galina Vishnevskaya, an 81-year-old opera singer, is wonderful as Alexandra.
An arty, cerebral film, Alexandra nevertheless speaks to the heart like a symphony.
Alexander Sokurov's Alexandra feels like a communiquÃ© from another time, another place, anywhere but here.
Aleksandr Sokurov's anti-war drama Alexandra opens with a curious image and spends 90 minutes squeezing it for all it's worth.
The mixture of the surreal and concrete feels remarkably accurate: a veritÃ© depiction of war with a profound ghostly quality.

Sokurov's sentimental poetry embroiders a nation's personal connections to the military; he shows the ineffable grace that contemporary American filmmakers are too pent up to grant us -- truths about fealty that our movies neglect.

[Sokurov is one of the] very few filmmakers with the technique, style, and sheer will to create strange, instantly accessible worlds that not only draw the viewer in, but also remain in the mind as places worthy of revisiting.
There's not a shot fired in the film, but it pierces the heart nonetheless.
It's a well-acted piece that finds a unique way to discuss the fortunes of soldiers and their families during times of war.
The images are indelible, if somewhat inscrutable (knowing Russian history would probably help, I suppose), but the message behind them rings out like a warning alarm.
Sokurov's excellent new Alexandra begins with an almost laughable scenario.
In the hands of visionary filmmaker Alexander Sokurov, this simple material makes for a haunting drama about war, generational relationships and the human condition.
... at times humorous, at times touching, and unfortunately, at times tedious and distancing.
...a film for the thoughtful, discerning filmgoer who is looking for something not made in the Hollywood, USA.
Alexandra is a pleasure to watch, but it's also one of those lovely, unclassifiable movies that flourishes better with repeated or prolonged exposures.
Alexandra washes over you like a gentle slice-of-life movie rather than polemic, with Vishnevskaya demanding your attention every moment she's onscreen.
The sepia tones and the claustrophobic camerawork are instantly recognizable as Sokurov's work, and so is the emphasis on family intimacy.
Every woman with a child in the military dreams about the mysterious environs of war into which her child has disappeared. Such a dream is the subject of Alexander Sokurov's astonishing Alexandra.
Clever scenario looks at the balance of power betwween age, sex, and nationality
Interesting look at life in the Russian military, but to what purpose?
One of those pure films that's devoid of excess and overstatement...simple but searing.

The film is built on a massive incongruity: Watching this octogenarian drag her little bent-up wheeled luggage cart, amid rolling tanks and military transport trucks, you're looking at two eternal verities%u2014war, and civilians caught up in its wake%u20
Remarkable, how little Sokurov tells us, while telling us so much.
Here is what filmmaking looks like at its absolute best: a movie of bold and aggressive originality that expresses itself with the utmost delicacy.
Perhaps Sokurov's film will leave some viewers as weary as its protagonist, but this intimate and evocative journey through war is well worth taking.

Sokurov is able to say things about the terrible conflict without obvious polemic but to the maximum possible effect. That's largely why he is one of the most audacious and original directors in the world today.
His sepia images of war's futility are beautiful, and Vishnevskaya's face is a compelling one, but they cannot compensate for the soporific anti-narrative.
The eerie haze of the visuals, the half-babble of music and the toneless, teasing dialogue dance attendance on the strangest ghost of all: Galina Vishnevskaya.
Shot in shades of bleached-out khaki brown and augmented by a heart-rending orchestral score, it's a unique and intensely moving elegy for wasted lives.
It's a film of small details rather than big gestures...and all the more powerful for it.
But Aleksandr Sokurov, with the mesmerising and subtly disorientating directorial style that he has mastered, makes it feel emotionally real and imaginatively true. A wonderful film.
A bone-weariness pervades every inch of the film; even the light is bleached dry of vitality.
Apart from a thoroughly irritating background track of schmaltzy classical music, this is Sokurov at his shortest and most digestible.
It's also quietly challenging, in its own way, not least in its portrait of old age, its trials, new freedoms and the privilege of changing one's mind before it becomes too late.
This is war as stalemate, with Aleksandr Burov's bleached images creating an alien landscape in which colour is as rare as compassion. Rarely has combat seemed so savage or futile.

At least one critic has called this Sokurov's most political film, but on its deepest level it considers not a particular war but the complex feelings between mothers and the young men they send out into the world to kill or be killed.
Eccentric and tender, it is a picture out for grace rather than polemics, and it finds enough to make one see emotional intimacy anew
An unusual masterpiece atmospheric anti-war film that is an example of cinema as pure feeling.

The film had so beautifully evoked this tenor of decamped emotional ties, of a people cared for forever traveling away from home, by conflating the grandmother's searching familial love with the isolated, forlorn faces of the soldiers...
Alexandra is a film made by someone who wants to talk, which is an admirable gesture. It's just not the correct one.
A rich and rewarding film, a deeply humanist work of art that is as tender as it is bracing.

movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
review_content: A well-balanced primer on the Arab-Israeli conflict, Blood and Tears takes just over an hour to go from the roots of Zionism to the recent electoral victory of Hamas.

movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
review_content: 'A small house can accommodate hundreds of friends, but can't accommodate two enemies,' the doctor says ruefully, quoting an Arab proverb. Sadly, Blood and Tears is the proof.

movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
review_content: Unless you've thrown up your hands and butted out of all news of the Middle East debacle, nothing in this methodical, unimaginative documentary about the Arab-Israeli conflict will surprise, edify or, God forbid, outrage you.

movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
review_content: Nothing more than a collection of sound bytes, most of them biased, many of them inflammatory, by a variety of speakers. It is hard to know what good this does.

movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
review_content: As the film progresses, it becomes increasingly bold in taking sides, while all the time pretending to be unbiased.

movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
review_content: Though refreshingly reluctant to take sides regarding geography of the matter, the film has a subtle slant toward peace.
...a fun, jazzy look at L.A.'s first real wave of modern artists
Morgan Neville's quick-paced documentary The Cool School recounts the rise and fall of Ferus Gallery and the mark it made on American art.
A lively film that doesn't linger too long on any one thought or with any one interviewee.
It is a fascinating journey through a piece of art history, the full impact of which may be yet to come.
What The Cool School does so well, through its color accents and black-and-white photography...is impart a sense of discovery.

No one emerges very well defined from this historical shuffle, but those who know the artists' works, or names such as Hopps and Blum, but have never heard them speak, will find The Cool School absorbing and informative.
All told, and well told, this is essential history.
Largely avoids sharply delineated portraits, with its focus on the scene at the expense of individuals, ultimately resulting in a documentary that doesn't rise above the functional.
Though designed more for the devotee of the arts than your average moviegoer, the film is still apt to enthrall even the uninitiated who wouldn't know a Jackson Pollock from a Willem de Kooning.

Documentarian Morgan Neville takes an appropriately lively, left-field approach to The Cool School's eye-opening history of the Beat-era Left Coast art scene -- a lesser-known chapter in the story of American modern art.
Surf's up in Southern California as the modern art world invades Nixonville and Reagan City in the 1950s. A fascinating look at the start of something big: modern art in Los Angeles.
Thoughtful and thought-provoking.
Diverting.
The Cool School, a breezy, lively documentary about a thin slice of the Los Angeles fine art scene in the 1950s, is easy on the eyes, and the ears too.
Cool School is a must for anyone interested in 20th century American art.
Definitely proves that, contrary to certain opinions, Los Angeles is not a cultural wasteland where fine art is concerned.
Sweeps you off your feet with quick-witted visuals and cleverly used archival footage.
Makes the case that there's more than basket weaving and freeway driving going on in the seedbed of originality we know as the Great Basin of L.A.
Breezy doc lives up to its title.
Veteran documentarist Morgan Neville's illustrated history of the painters and sculptors associated with Venice's Ferus Gallery (1957-1967) is at once lively and analytical.
The Cool School is neither as lively nor as complete as it could be, but as an introduction to modern art, it's a fine freshman course.
The Cool School is a history of the LA art scene which will be most interesting for those who are involved in it.
Occasionally too reverent, this remains an effective evocation of a vibrant and interesting art scene, not to mention a touching paean to lost youth.

Morgan Neville's 'The Cool School' is a slickly packaged document of the burgeoning modern art scene in LA during the late '50s and early '60s which sadly submerges its fascinating subject matter in technical clutter and contrived set-ups.
Neville's film shows, in effect, how deliberate the founding of an art movement can be. But also how thrilling it is for those at the eye of the storm.
An intense, sexy medical thriller that gives us a glimpse of what CSI would look like if it were a horror.
Medical thriller mixes extreme violence, sex.
If you are a hardcore fan of films like FLATLINERS, I guarantee that you'll dig this flick... PATHOLOGY is really a gem that doesn't deserve to be overlooked.
One of the more effective and chilling thrillers released this year.
Not exactly a great movie, but it's sick, slick, and strange enough to warrant a 90-minute look.
When a movie opens with the diner scene from When Harry Met Sally as performed by cadavers, and later proceeds to sex scenes involving scalpels and needles, the actual plot becomes inconsequential.
An inordinately sleazy medical thriller operating on the erroneous belief that the combination of hot sex and cold corpses constitutes a real turn-on.
This is the film that should have been called "Coma"
Slickly made but utterly gratuitous, this wannabe-edgy thriller was an odd choice for Ventimiglia to make during his first Heroes hiatus.
It's as if [director] Schoelermann and screenwriters Mark Neveldine and Brian Taylor had more of a concept than a concrete idea.
A particularly nasty slice of medical-themed horror, Marc Scholermann's film is the sort of thriller in which the tenderest scene depicts an autopsy.
Much like Crank, it's the guiltiest of guilty pleasures.

Even squeamish viewers are apt to be captivated by the tight, credible scripting; these 20-somethings talk and behave like today's irony-clad young sophisticates. And whatever your opinion of the subject matter, you can't fault the filmmaking.
Like its characters, the pic is too clever for its own good, allowing the meticulously researched scenario to be undone by implausible behavior and gaping plot holes.
As dull as a conversation with a corpse.
Gleefully brimming with body parts and bad behavior, Pathology is a fun piece of flamboyant tastelessness.
Existing somewhere in a world between Flatliners, Saw and Last Tango in Paris, this oversexed, over the top, underwritten medical horror flick won't come anywhere near the success of those films.
Comes off as a semi-absurd variant of the horror mystique cheating the potentials of impeccable production values.
To put things into perspective, the campier "Saw" films are all better -- and more clever ...
...a sporadically compelling yet hopelessly inconsequential piece of work.
This new Christmas Carol starring Jim Carrey will scare the bejesus out of small children!
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Conceptually brilliant with mind-blowing special effects, but who is the intended audience of this visual extravaganza? Certainly not children: the content is far too dark with haunting imagery that could provoke nightmares for impressionable youngsters
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: If Disney invested in this because they were hoping for an annual re-release and an easy cash cow every time the season rolls around, I think they'll be disappointed.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A clear step in the right direction for Zemeckis and his pet techno-project, the film nonetheless ultimately sabotages itself by prizing the hectic over the heartfelt.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: This Carol has a worse identity crisis than Scrooge. Clinging to the novel, the film tries to break out of its insular theatrics to propel Scrooge and his supernatural helpmates into outer space, as if in takeoff into a different sci-fi comic book movie.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The director has brought this Charles Dickens classic to such vivid life that in some ways you feel like you are experiencing it for the first time
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A Christmas Carol is a whiz-bang 3-D thrill-ride with all the emotional satisfaction squeezed out of it.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis' motion-capture animated features continue to be odd presents, offering undeniable technical skill with a host of other obstacles hindering total enjoyment.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: There are nightmarish images, ghostly themes and a feeling that it might be a bit much for kids, but it's a touching film with visuals that will blow your mind. It's a trip.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Bob Hoskins looks just right as kind old Mr. Fezziwig, but that may be more of a testament to the actor's physiognomy than to the motion-capture process, which makes most of the film's cast look like they just sauntered out of Madame Tussauds.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A Christmas Carol is, in its essence, a product reel, a showy, exuberant demonstration of the glories of motion capture, computer animation and 3D technology. On that level, it's a wow. On any emotional level, it's as cold as Marley's Ghost.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Shortchanging traditional animation by literalizing it while robbing actors of their full range of facial expressiveness, the performance-capture technique favored by director Robert Zemeckis looks more than ever like the emperor's new clothes.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A Christmas Carol is an engaging and relatively dark take on a seasonal classic that finds director Robert Zemeckis refining the performance capture animation technique he used to mixed effect on The Polar Express and Beowulf.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: By the time it's over, you'll have to be a real Scrooge yourself to not have at least a little bit of the Christmas spirit instilled into you.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: This is a faithful retelling of the story, proving that strong tales such as these are better off without embellishment. The enhancements here come, not to the source material but to the look of the film, which is beautifully rendered in immersive 3D.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A moody picture of extraordinary technical achievement, not a glazed retelling of holiday reform. The distance is unavoidable, but my hope is that audiences take the opportunity to drink in the astonishing craftsmanship of the film.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Disney's A Christmas Carol is a marvelous and touching yuletide toy of a movie, and the miracle is that it goes right back to the gilded Victorian spirit of those black-and-white films of yore.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis' latest motion-capture CGI project capsizes Dickens' narrative power simply because the faces of the human simulacra are so utterly inexpressive and ugly.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Against the odds, this Disney version, written and directed by Robert Zemeckis, could be the best adaptation to date of the story.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Charles Dickens' classic story hasn't been revitalized but it has been faithfully and capably recreated.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Even as [Zemeckis] uses the 3D process to turn A Christmas Carol into a rollercoaster ride through a solidly built fantasy world, he never forgets that at bottom the tale is an awful warning about how egoism and greed can destroy your humanity.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: All style and no substance, Disney's A Christmas Carol is a yawn inducing retread of a tired fable.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Utilizing performance-capture technology, it's intricate and ingenious, offering a 3-D fantasy/adventure thrill ride, soaring into the holiday season.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Thankfully, this Christmas Carol is Scrooge-centric...and, thanks to an unusually layered performance by Jim Carrey, that mostly saves the day for this film.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Charles Dickens' lifelong wish to have his story retold as a three-dimensional cartoon has finally been realized. At last his soul may be at peace.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: 3-D adaptation of classic holiday tale may scare young kids.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: If you've ever wanted to see what 3D could actually do for a film if it wasn't just used as a gimmick then check out A Christmas Carol.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Parental Content Review
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Children not already familiar with the past iterations of A Christmas Carol will be in heaven if they can get past the spookier elements, while the rest of viewers will be happy with, if not quite euphoric for, what Robert Zemeckis has cooked up.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Happily, despite all the ornamentation in this 3-D adaptation, the pic remains mostly faithful to the novel, while only occasionally devolving into spectacle.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Just when you give up on it, usually in the middle of its latest, extraneous, gyroscoping thrill-ride sequence, Zemeckis reminds you that he's capable of true visual dynamism, enhanced but not wholly dictated by the digital landscape he so clearly adores.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Carrey's Scrooge is deliciously pinched and credible. As, indeed, is this film -- that is, when it feels like Dickens and not a theme park ride.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Have we learned nothing from The Klumps?
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: To put it bluntly, if Scroogely, Disney's 3-D animated version of A Christmas Carol is a calamity.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: By the time A Christmas Carol finishes piling its many shiny presents with their many bells and whistles under the tree, there's no room left for tears for Tiny Tim. Bah humbug indeed.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: This motion-capture animated adaptation is a real Christmas cracker.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis' movie may lack the emotional impact of the 1951 British version of A Christmas Carol, starring Alastair Sim as a truly transformed and happy Scrooge. Nevertheless, it's a visual treat that respects and artfully enhances its source.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Enough elements of Dickens's story remain for a viewer to be refreshed by Scrooge's change of heart, and to be moved by his rediscovery of the Christmas spirit that climaxes the story.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A re-telling should either present a resonant or fresh thematic take. This Christmas Carol seems like a pale ghost of Dickens' magical Christmas classic.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Carrey's performance as the miserly misanthrope is lost amid effects more typically encountered in theme-park and video-game adventures. (P.S.: Is it just me, or does it also peeve you that the Mouse House claims proprietary rights on Dickens' title?)
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: There's some dazzling stuff here. But you get creepy, dead-eyed and inexpressive performances - even sympathetic characters end up looking like the ventriloquist's doll in that Anthony Hopkins movie.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It's nice of Hollywood to go to all the trouble but, honestly, Dickens doesn't need the help.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Charles Dickens wrote the book 50 years before movies even existed. He wrote for the imagination. And until now, movies haven't been able to measure up.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It's an unengaging, dull adaptation that has nothing really new to say in regards to the already-much-told tale.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Shockingly, the new film turns out to be very good, at times close to brilliant: a darkly detailed marvel of creative visualization that does well by Dickens and right by audiences -- when it's not trying to sell them a theme park ride.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The holiday spirit feels real, but the film does not.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Clear evidence of the limitations of the performance-capture method of animation and of the excesses it invites...there's more of artifice than art in it.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The utter freedom of camera movement evokes a visceral sense of buoyant jubilation that immediately connects us to the movie's setting.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It's visually stunning and all, but this is one version of A Christmas Carol that the world can probably live without. Humbug!
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: All I want for Christmas is for Robert Zemeckis to stop making mo-cap movies.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: If you want realism, use actors. If you want animation, use your imagination. Sadly, imagination is missing from this technically impressive but emotionally inert film.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It's eerie rather than wondrous.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It's not that Carrey fails in this serious guise, but, rather, it strips the comic actor of everything that makes him so special.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Too much of the film is geared around 3-D wizardry. Unneeded sequences pop up for purely "wow" baiting.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A leaden and ugly mess that offers all the emotional and dramatic heft of an exceptionally garish Christmas window display.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Robert Zemeckis finds eye-popping, high-tech new life in Dickens' hoary chestnut.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The best part of this Christmas Carol is the end, when the ugly animation metamorphoses back into the pages of a book.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The story that Dickens wrote in 1838 remains timeless, and if it's supercharged here with Scrooge swooping the London streets as freely as Superman, well, once you let ghosts into a movie, there's room for anything.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: By Fezziwig, that story still works and tugs at the heart. It would even if each ghost's visit weren't scored with overly-suitable Christmas carols.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: In spite of its holiday trappings, A Christmas Carol is an incredibly bleak look into the deepest and darkest human fears, but it is also a vibrant celebration of our better natures.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: In this morality tale, which winds up playing like the advertisement for an amusement park ride, Scrooge is supposed to be afraid of the truth, not the ghosts.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A refreshing update of Dickens' timeless tale.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The whole enterprise is just so empty and pointless, a bunch of bland technical wizardry that will be dated in five years.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Writer-director Robert Zemeckis follows Charles Dickens' 1843 novella, A Christmas Carol, so closely that he even makes the same error the author made with the first edition of the book.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: You don't need glasses -- 3-D or otherwise -- to see that this holiday release is too diluted for adults, too frightening for children, and too tiresome for just about everybody.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Most of us know the beginning, middle, and uplifting end. However, the hook this time is a trifecta: 3-D, digital imagery, and Jim Carrey. That hook makes this 'Christmas Carol' worth seeing.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A garish and tedious animated interpretation of the Charles Dickens classic that has neither heart nor soul.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Boasts dazzling CGI effects and important moral lessons, but it suffers from excessive style over substance while lacking the genuine, unadulturated warmth, emotional resonance and soul of the Dickens classic.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Scrooge's ultimate transformation to kindness and charity comes too late and is given little screen time. Carrey never gets a chance to be the funny comedian that has endeared him to his legion of fans.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: There are already so many great adaptions of the classic Dickens story %u2013 this one adds nothing but CGI and gimmicky 3D effects.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis seems unable to admit that the motion capture animation he's been using on The Polar Express and Beowulf is an artistic dead end.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: exactly what I expected from Zemeckis and company. With the Dickens story as the foundation, it's perfect for the holiday season
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Yes, Zemeckis does throw in a few gratuitous moments where things are flying at your face, but he ends up using enough restraint to ensure the 3D doesn't overwhelm your senses or take away from Dickens' stirring story about greed and redemption.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The only major change Disney's A Christmas Carol takes with the source material is draining the humanity right out of it.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: How they made it into this Disney adaptation unprettified is a Christmas miracle in itself.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis... appears to have given up making fantasies for grownups in favor of making theme-park attractions designed to do nothing more than shut the kiddies up for 90 minutes...
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: In the end you don't have to analyze it... that tear in your eye tells you it's working.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Too bad though, that for all the eye-popping spirits on screen, it lacks a soul.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Although Dickens has been translated time and time again, this animated adventure is no humbug.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Call me a Scrooge, but I'll pass on this synthetic version of that most humanistic of tales.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis' film preserves much of Dickens' original dialogue and detail while amplifying the utter ethereal strangeness of the ghosts.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: There's a lot of dark magic in this Dickensian Yuletide.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Want the creeps for Christmas? Then check out the latest version of A Christmas Carol.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Does this entertainment achieve a timelessness beyond its exquisite source material? Not even. Yet there's pleasure to be had and relief in feeling the filmmakers didn't Scrooge it up either.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Disney's excessively hyped A Christmas Carol brings Dickensian details to such sumptuous life that you mostly forgive it for possessing a stop-motion soul.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The movie may be yet another retelling of an iconic story, but visually it is often quite breathtaking.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis captures all the story's terror, but its pathos has always been the real challenge, and it mostly eludes him.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: You don't identify with Scrooge at any point, nor is blatant fakery scary. Picture The Seventh Seal with sock puppets.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A branded piece of shiny seasonal entertainment.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Robert Zemeckis turns the classic Dickens tale into a 3D performance-capture spectacle, abetted by the versatility of Jim Carrey as skinflint Scrooge and his ghostly visitors.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Succeeds in delivering a respectful--if not always magical--interpretation of Dickens' famous tale.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: all science and little sentiment
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It feels like Zemeckis wanted to make one movie (a socially relevant ghost story) and Disney wanted another (a Polar Express-type movie). It doesn't work.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The good news about A Christmas Carol, then, is that Dickens' story -- the pure power of it, the grace and gentleness, the sensibility and sentiment of it -- cannot be drowned or destroyed no matter how many technicians and dollars are thrown at it.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A splendidly mounted and visually imaginative animated 3D version of the classic novel.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: For the most part, Zemeckis delivers a faithful interpretation of Dickens' work in this PG-rated holiday tale. What he misses out on capturing is the spirit of Dickens' story.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: ...a remarkable and effective adaptation of Charles Dickens' classic novel that manages to overcome the familiarity of its source material and become something more fulfilling.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: this is not the Scrooge McDuck or Mr. Magoo version of the classic Charles Dickens tale, this A Christmas Carol is the dark, challenging and frightening version of the story
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Cinematographer Robert Presley and the design team provide many instances of graphical triumph, influenced by silent cinema.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: As for this 'performance capture,' rife with characters sporting the annoying wandering eye, it might be time for an intervention, ghostly or not. You're a filmmaker, Mr. Z, not a puppeteer. Enough is enough.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: This Hollywood adaptation is as glossy as Christmas wrapping paper and just as disposable.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A Christmas Carol should be as cosy and familiar as piping-hot tea and buttered, toasted crumpets, not a brain-battering sensory assault that feels like downing tequila shots on a rollercoaster.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: There is a weird lack of passion here, almost condescension, a sense that Scrooge's agonised moral journey into his past is potentially pretty dull, and so Zemeckis is always livening things up by whooshing the old miser excitingly through the night sky.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis has succeeded is transforming a staid and over-familiar story into a rip-roaring and viscerally powerful special effects chase-movie.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The whizzing pyrotechnics aren't quite enough to make this a Christmas classic.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A Christmas Carol is certainly set to win the nation's attention. With all this hype, we'd hoped for something a bit more special.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It is an experience, being stunning to look at -- and you'll only get the full effect from seeing it on the big screen, rather than waiting for the DVD.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis brightens up the screen with beautiful visual effects but had trouble bringing anything new to this already amazing story that we have heard a million times before.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Charles Dickens's reflective, universal story becomes fodder for a technological thrill ride starring a rough approximation of Jim Carrey.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Sometimes the richness of the visual banquet threatens to leave viewers with Christmas afternoon indigestion yet never stops you feeling hungry for more.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: In a very real sense, this version of A Christmas Carol is the most faithful to Charles Dickens' original text ever filmed.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A strikingly animated and thoroughly magical 3-D adaptation... that, counter to so many other versions, beautifully captures the darkly intense vibe of Dickens' ghost story.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It's a heartwarmer that doesn't have much of a heart itself.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: If you want an entertaining period piece, you could do a lot worse than attend Robert Zemeckis' A Christmas Carol.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Disney's excessively hyped A Christmas Carol revels so richly in bringing the Dickensian details to sumptuous life that you wind up forgiving it for possessing a stop-motion soul.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A near-perfect blend of looks and heart.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A technically proficient but disturbing adaptation (that) adopts a surprisingly macabre tone.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: It's like taking a Christmas wreath and dipping it in wax or laminating a Christmas card in plastic. Zemeckis risks creating another Yule ghoul: the Ghost of Christmas Without Soul.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: As the lead character, Carrey's CG-created body is spindly and bent, and he has fun with his vocal performance, turning every word into a strangled hiss.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The use of 3-D leaves the not unpleasant sensation that snow is gently falling throughout the entire cinema. A respectable, high-tech stab at an old favourite but the Alastair Sim version remains the best.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: After round two in Jim Carrey vs. Holiday Classics, it's Carrey 2, Classics 0.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Full of Christmas cheer this is not.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: The story is robust enough to survive the theme-park treatment, and for the most part it's a very good ride, with a welcome note of actual Christmas caroling spirit.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Dickens purists can stay away. Others can feel free to sample the rollicking aerial views of Victorian London, the droll and scary elasticity of Carrey.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Scores high on swooping visuals and meticulous draughtsmanship.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: There's no warmth from these spooky, human-modelled digitised automatons, who glide about like all-night trance festival-goers the morning after.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Despite the obvious care given the story, at its heart it is a dry lump of coal. This "Christmas Carol" is curiously remote and cold.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A Christmas Carol is a worthy stab at mixing old and new, a vintage tale done with some fresh dazzle and a reminder that the movies can still bring the wow.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Leaves a lot to be desired, and it's a virtual grab bag of good ideas mixed with bad.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: [It's] not something you should say bah humbug to.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: At its best, this revamp gets the eerie oppressiveness of London fog and Marley's rattling chains just right -- we all know the moral, but Zemeckis does remind us what a spine-chilling yarn it is.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Unfortunately, as good as the animation is, it never quite manages to bring any of the characters to life and the film fails to connect on an emotional level as a result.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: For most of us, all the surprises here are visual, and it's well worth seeing in 3D.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: As a movie to get you in the Christmas spirit, A Christmas Carol does its job nicely.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: A visual extravaganza with dazzling special effects.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Really, who cares? The essence of the story has been lost in the process. Give me The Muppet Christmas Carol any day.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: There is an almost constant deadness to the eyes that is deeply distracting, while each person's movements are so ungainly and wild even Gumby would look at them all wandering around and wonder why they look so uncomfortably odd.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Animatronic robots would feel more human than this.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Zemeckis tries to juice things up by staging numerous chase scenes up and around London, but do we really need "A Christmas Carol: The Action Picture"?
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Mr. Zemeckis has always been a talented, if less than subtle, director. And his "Carol" is never dull. But it also never justifies its own existence.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: As a dedicated fan of Charles Dickens' works, I also am a dedicated fan of several versions of his classic "A Christmas Carol."
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Hold onto your mug of warm apple cider. This newest, action-packed version of A Christmas Carol could get a little bumpy.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: An exquisitely crafted visual experience.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Seeming spawned from some ghoulish dream I felt nothing warm or symbolic of a tradition from this film.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Are the less than perfectly executed bits supposed to set off the truly terrific ones, or are the truly terrific ones supposed to distract the viewing audience from the bits that go clunk in the night?
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: ...we never experience that moment when Scrooge's heart melts. He seems already changed the moment Marley leaves him.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: Yes %u2014 I am giving A Christmas Carol a high rating. It is technical perfection and brilliantly done. However, it is too much Zemeckis, too much Carrey. Not enough Dickens.
genres: Animation, Drama, Kids & Family, Science Fiction & Fantasy

review_content: [An] expertly assembled and engrossing documentary.
Charting the thin line between courage and foolhardiness, it's a poignant portrayal of the excruciating emotional odyssey of all involved.
A sad story, but well told, with respect for its subject and an eye for the Shakespearian tragedy in the tale.

Stories celebrating heroic journeys are commonplace, but this is a sobering, anti-heroic tale of an ordinary man who set out to attempt the extraordinary... and failed through a cruel combination of bad luck and bad judgement.
The pic should suck even landlubbers into a whirlpool of gripping adventure, overblown ambitions and sheer human folly.
Deep Water confirms all the mythical terrors that lurk in our dreams of the sea, and the best person to watch it with would be Melville.
Given that the tedium of months on the open seas could and did drive a man insane, co-directors Louise Osmond and Jerry Rothwell have done a commendable job of making Deep Water... well, not boring.
It is the point -- and the power -- of Deep Water that the vast, unknowable fathoms of the sea are rivaled only by those of the human psyche.
A true-life tale of inadvertent self-destruction, Deep Water's generic title belies its haunting incisiveness.
Not only is this an incredible saga of Jack London proportions, it's also a great detective tale.
Echoes the dark poetry of Coleridge's Ancient Mariner and Poe's Arthur Gordon Pym, men who sailed to sea in search of fortune only to encounter the abyss within themselves.
His story is a footnote in sailing history, to be sure, but a fascinating one.
Humane and haunting.
Deep Water successfully combines the pressure of the competition with an intriguing character study of the increasingly desperate Crowhurst.
In a sense, the subject of this film contributed a good deal of material to his cinematic biography, material that is gut-wrenchingly intimate and revelatory.
Nearly 40 years after he attempted to transcend his everyday life of limited horizons and money troubles, Osmond and Rothwell offer a fitting tribute to Crowhurst and his impossible dream.
A spooky, moving doc that chronicles the first solo attempt to circle the world by boat.
Deep Water is a documentary, but it's also one part adventure film, one part Greek tragedy, and one part meditation on the role of the 'hero' in modern society.
An enthralling documentary about an Englishman named Donald Crowhurst who, in 1968, set off on a solitary, nonstop circumnavigation of the globe.
Deep Water's account of a modern Icarus is frighteningly clear in its perceptions and aftershocks.
A fascinating documentary about the first single-handed around-the-world sailing race, begins like a Boy's Own adventure tale but ends up more akin to tragedy.
Remarkable.
The documentary effectively blends contemporary and recent interviews with film and tape recordings made by Crowhurst aboard the Electron.
One of this year's better studies of the human soul.
Osmond and Rothwell do a commendable job of mining a rich archive of material.
Osmond and Rothwell's depiction of his unraveling is an exquisitely structured drama.
To reveal Crowhurst's decision would be to spoil a stunning tale. Deep Water is not itself comparably stunning.
Despite the flaws in the structure and story of Deep Water, Osmond and Rothwell display great skill at keeping their audience informed.
One of the year's best documentaries.

Deep Water is a stunning documentary that not only beautifully elucidates a nearly forgotten incident but touches on crucial themes involving isolation, sanity, self-worth, impossible dreams, the nature of heroism and limits of human endurance.
...a compelling portrait of a man who is terminally befuddled and ends up abandoning his wife and children because he can't face the music.
A tangle of turbulent seas and emotions.
It is a sad, finely crafted documentary that must not be missed, if you call yourself a real film buff.
But more startling are the original tape recordings and 16mm films made by the solitary competitors as they spent more than ten months alone trying to sail around the globe.
For this gripping and amazing documentary, such truth emerges not just from the facts, but also the poetry of men who redefine themselves in a risky race on small sailboats.
This isn't primarily an adventure story, though it's very suspenseful; it's first and foremost a profoundly sad tale of human frailty.
With the discovery of films and audiotape from the first solo, non-stop nautical race around the globe, Deep Water promises to take us where we have never been.
This was a story that made front pages in its day but has been largely lost to history, and now is brought bracingly and compellingly back to life.
Some beautiful shots give unexpected texture to the film, such as an underwater capture of a boat from below, with prisms of light surrounding it. And its final image is a quiet heartbreaker.
...the less said about this film the better. It's that good.
This well crafted and engaging documentary is a ripping yarn of a man's mansize adventure going horribly wrong.
This is pretty heady stuff, and it's constantly enthralling, particularly for something that has to use so much second-hand information.
Not merely a documentary portrait, but an engrossing drama with more twists and turns than your average thriller.
Deeply researched and compellingly presented, Deep Water is as much about one man's misadventures on the ocean as it is about loneliness, desperation and the danger of dreams.
The film evokes a visceral understanding of solitude at sea.
This is fascinating stuff... that would be better served by a magazine article or book.

As directed by Louise Osmond and Jerry Rothwell, the movie breezes along at a highly watchable clip, thanks to fluid, affecting intercutting of archival, black-and-white footage and present-day interviews.
As a portrait of obsession, competition and, finally, delusion, Deep Water is haunting and engrossing, and one of the best nonfiction movies of the year.
Knowing in advance how it all turned out cannot rob this remarkable movie of any of its drama, although ignorance of the events probably adds to the kick.
The details just get stranger and stranger.
I do think the movie loses focus at times, but nevertheless, this is a pretty interesting story into madness.
engaging
... hopefully what I write might encourage someone to seek out a film. Such is the case with Road to Victory, the debut feature of writer-director-actor Mike Reilly.
